pros: The clients make this job great. You’ll gain valuable experience over a short amount of time.
cons:
Since day one, I have not felt welcome by my colleagues at NYLAG. Thankfully I’ve found two colleagues that are supportive but that’s about it. I often feel like colleagues are trying to undermine one another and on more than one occasion I have been belittled by colleagues or have received passive aggressive treatment. 
The supervision is also minimal and you will have to be your own supervisor at times. Supervisors sometimes have just as much experience as you do. Colleagues also do not have much experience, but claim otherwise because they are extremely insecure.

job_title: Staff Attorney in New York, NY
pros: Recently unionized, pay middle of the road. Good work/life balance, except in housing and immigration units (though I hear housing has gotten better lately). Recently more focus on racial equity in promotion. Payroll is never late and they tend to have good HR/resources and all the great benefits of a big professional nonprofit.
cons: Lower pay than MFJ or LSNY, and no official training regimen as of 2020. Office located centrally in FiDi--no branch offices, which can be bad if that's an issue for your commute. Recent unionization and all of the usual angst that leads to that, but they did recently get a contract (I believe in October 2020 with a modest pay raise).

pros: Colleagues were intelligent and truly kind people for the most part. Great benefits and time off.

pros: 1. Office space is comfortable. 2. Interview process is quick. 3. Paralegals age range between 21-26. As a Millennial there are ample peers you can interact with. 4. Most higher ups keep to themselves unless there are concerns with your performance, case or peer. 5. Salary as an entry level position is a reasonable about. Salary is definitely based on experiences and capabilities.  I recommend only for a very short period of time. They prefer a two year stay however, I had to leave after a year. No growth.
cons: 1. CEO is only responsive when (s)he is scheduled to interact with staff. There is a sense of favoritism for some over others. 2. Attorneys do not all get along. A lot of conflict of power between your assigned supervisor and the attorneys your caseload is linked to. 3. Training is only given upon constant request otherwise the staff assumes you are aware of all NYLAG information and processes. 4. CEO is not very genuine and does not concern herself with the paralegal unit as much as it is claimed to be enforced. You must make sure to keep appearances with CEO or else work gets piled towards you and you become targeted. Benefits, however are very reasonable for entry level position.

review_title: Great learning experience - disappointing work environment
pros:
-Amazing colleagues! I have had the opportunity to work with some of the brightest, most dedicated attorneys in New York who work tirelessly for the benefit of NYLAG's clientele.
-Lots of independence and a great learning experience for new attorneys (both a positive and negative) great if you are lucky to get a great manager that takes the time to train you.
- Ability to transfer within the company so lots of opportunity to get exposure to a variety of work.
- Decent Salary for a Public interest position
cons:
- Lack of transparency
- Lack of company culture
- Overwhelming workload (depending on unit)
- Abusive clients
- Severe lack of diversity in attorney and management - and a leadership that is apathetic to this. 
- Lack of appreciation for staff in general - "suck it up" "it is what it is" type environment
- Units operate independently and do not work well or even communicate with each other even on cases that over lap.
- Not every unit operates that well - its kind of a crap shoot.  You might get good training you might get no training work loads are not equal at all.
- Little to no opportunities for advancement/promotion
- In one particular unit a series of bad promotions and hires led to over 60% of the attorneys quitting within the course of a year...completely destroyed a great team.

pros: Dedicated staff, able to do meaningful work, lots of responsibility even as a new employee
cons: Hit or miss supervisors, pay is not enough

review_title: Important work, typical non-profit bureaucracy/White savior complex
pros: The clients are really incredible and the work is important. Coworkers were very bright and passionate people.
cons: Management suffers from typical White savior complex. More receptive to feedback than most though

pros: Rewarding work, caring and intelligent staff, reasonable hours
cons: Not a lot of opportunity for upward mobility

review_title: Nice place to work for non-profit
pros: Good benefits and time off.
cons: not a lot of upward movement for people without law degrees

pros: Collegial environment where you are treated with respect

review_title: Great work environment with caring leadership.
job_title: Staff Attorney in New York, NY
pros: Great work environment and Benefits
cons: pay is not very competitive for attorneys.

review_title: Great first job out of college, but no opps for advancement (so have an exit plan)
pros:
- Hands-on experience helping underserved communities
- If you're right out of college, you'll make tons of friends as I did. Lots of 20-somethings, which gives it a fun, collegial atmosphere
- Passionate, smart, tough colleagues who know their sh*t
- Good work-life balance--good vacation policy, never had to take work home with me, etc
- Lots of webinars and trainings, opps to learn about topical areas of law
cons:
- Very hands-off management/supervision. Felt like I was navigating some tricky client situations alone. No one has time to help you, everyone is so busy with their own caseload
- Really no opportunities to advance as a paralegal. Most paras stay 1.5 year and then leave for law school. Ensure you have an exit strategy to grad school or another job. I stayed past 2 years and was very restless at the end (my own fault)
- Pay was low when I started but they've boosted a bit in the last few years
- More structured check-in process needed b/n paras and supervisors

review_title: CEO needs to provide a safe work environment for transparency, for employee growth and social interaction.
pros: Cubicle space is sufficient, there’s a food court in building.
cons: There are a lot of cliques. Supervisors and CEO need more training on how to interact with staff, not a very welcoming place.

pros: It was a great experience to be working side by side with attorneys.  I really got a feel for the law industry working with these attorneys and paralegals.  Everyone is very collegial but its still a work hard environment.  There are lots of other interns and volunteers to meet with and that also made the experience a lot of fun.
cons: Senior management does not seem to be timely with notices.  Many Fridays, the President would close the office early and not let anyone know until the day of.  It didn't annoy me so much as it annoyed lots of the attorneys.  Receptionists, which are about 3 or 4 women, tend to goof off a lot and curse loudly in the office.  It's very unprofessional as there are many outside volunteer attorneys that can hear them in addition to interns.

review_title: Talented staff, out of touch management
job_title: Housing (Tenants Rights Unit) in New York, NY
pros:
Passionate, talented co-workers
Really nice office space in a good location
Grants that feel secure
cons:
Top heavy org with a lot of overpaid executive staff (too much concern with PR and not enough going into funding legal work, legislative action/policy work and grant writing)
Lack of experience & maturity in low-mid level management
Insufficient internal training/institutional knowledge 
Tarnished name after major scandal circa 2015

pros: There are many different units, and there's a lot of freedom to develop new projects and take initiative.  There are some very passionate attorneys who care deeply about providing quality legal services.
cons: The units can be silo-ed, without being able to effectively collaborate.   In the immigration unit, the leadership takes on challenging cases without having the knowledge to support the work.  For that reason, supervision is often lacking because they aren't aware of their own limitations.

pros: NYLAG is a great place to work if you know how it fits in your long term plan. Young professionals looking to go into the legal field will find the support and resources necessary to advance.
cons: I worked in a demanding unit where people just “ended up”.  If you just “end up” at NYLAG you might find yourself both bored and overworked. My colleagues were passionate advocates, but not a single one of them liked the work. This disconnect created a petty, divisive, boring, and alcoholic work environment. The people who did best in my unit were those who understood how they were going to use the work they were doing at NYLAG to go somewhere else.

review_title: Great on some things, not so great on others
pros: Very pro-diversity workplace culture. There are gender neutral bathrooms for trans* or genderqueer persons, and even those who aren't use them so it's totally normalized. There is an actively encouraging culture around racial, sexual orientation, and gender diversity.
cons: The hierarchy is very tangible. If you're low down on the totem poll you know it, and even if it's not in your job description you may be assigned to randomly take notes from an exec.'s voicemail so that they don't have to go through it themselves.

job_title: Staff Attorney in New York, NY
pros: mostly great co-workers. interesting cases. benefits are decent. recently voted to unionize.
cons: supervisors and management aren't helpful nor do they try to address concerns. your experience at nylag is dictated by your supervisor because there aren't many opportunities to collaborate with coworkers on cases. so if you dislike your supervisor you're sol because they will not reassign you. but most of the supervisors aren't great anyway so you're still sol. benefits are good but other nonprofits in the area have better benefits and better salaries. not as diverse as it could be. very concerned about optics and branding instead of focusing on their mission.

job_title: Staff Attorney in New York, NY
pros: I had a significant amount of independence and was able to pursue special interests to the extent that doing so was appropriate for my position. I gained an extensive client communication and litigation experience across a range of substantive areas and worked in a range of different contexts, from federal court, civil court and administrative agencies.
cons: Supervisors are spread thin, so it is difficult to get feedback on your work; if you are not an independent worker or lack confidence, it might be difficult to adjust to. Based on my observations and without any inside information, funders and grants play too large a role in defining the work, which should be defined by the needs of the clients.

pros: It is extremely rewarding to work with New York's low-income residents. They greatly appreciate you when you help them secure a right that someone has encroached on or help them to achieve a legal outcome that without your help they probably would not have even been able to dream possible. At NYLAG there is also a relatively strong familial atmosphere, and given the large number of young staff and forward-thinking attorneys you are blessed to work with modern professional who are doing very interesting public-interest work. Because of the flexible management style, you can initiate your own projects and take on assignments that really challenge and cultivate your professional skills. There is certainly a lot of lateral movement within the organization that can really contribute to strengthening your resume , as a young professional, and helping to take the next step into a more higher level position. You are definitely prepared to do a lot of work!
cons: There is a decentralized management system: each unit manages itself and is responsible for securing funding. Because our legal services are to a degree a function of broader political hot-topics (i.e. foreclosure) it would behoove management to have a general fund and then have the board of directors distribute money internally. This would keep certain units from going bankrupt (which is what is pretty much happening within my unit). In my case, this problem is also due to poor management and very little accountability by the director of my specific unit. There is also a bit of the high school lunchroom feel at times- I guess that's the downside of having a fresh-out-of-college crowd. The downside of the loose management style is that rules are often enforced at the whim of personal discretion; there is definitely a George Orwell-1984-esque feeling of  "some animals are more equal than others". You are encouraged to work a 9-5 although it isn't really realistic given the breadth of work you have to accomplish and you better budget very very carefully (read penny pinching!) if you're going to live in New York on your own off of it. The worst of it however, is that there is no real Human Resources department; there is definitely a benefit department, but if you have an inter-office issue that needs to be troubleshot, there is no one there who is trained to facilitate and resolve those kinds of issues in an imparcial manner.

review_title: Lots of work, and you learn about yourself
pros: If you are willing to do it they always have work, as it seems like the case at most nonprofits. I did 2 clinics back to back, picked up some Spanish, got home at 11 or 12, came to the office at night to finish stuff, they give you a lot of responsibility and you're expected to rise to the challenge. You get to really interact with a lot of clients, to analyze their cases, suggest things to your supervisor, and they teach a lot about how to be meticulous and accurate and thorough. I'm the type of person who really gets into cases and while it's hard to communicate that kind of attitude since it's something I inherited from working long federal felony dockets where you're constantly getting things thrown at you but in a more predictable way, this was a challenge, and they let me have it and I enjoyed it.
cons: The clientele skewed heavily towards several demographics I'm not proficient with language wise and there was a pretty strict way of doing things that can be difficult to fit into, as I came from a field that had a ton of flexibility, but such is the case with administrative law. And it's part of the nature of the work but there are times when you can't reach any of your clients and all of a sudden they all call at once and to someone who's not used to managing cases on the client's time - I had just spent over 2 years doing defense work and my clients tended to have more flexible schedules - it gets tough sometimes.

review_title: If you want a mentor look elsewhere...
job_title: Staff Attorney in New York, NY
pros: Salary is competitive.  You are left completely on your own to manage your own schedule.
cons:
You are left completely on your own without anyone overseeing what you do. 
 I recently presented a 2 hour CLE and not only did my supervisor not stick their head in, no one above me asked to check the presentation or even acknowledge that it even occurred.  It is very much an "every  man for himself" work type environment.  
I have NEVER been told I've done a good job or received any accolades, despite winning many difficult cases.
My unit is in a constant low level panic with everyone is trying to avoid taking "crazy" and "unreasonable " clients - you receive zero support from above if they are dishonest or untruthful with you.  The clients rule the roost, even to the detriment of the attorneys - borderline malpractice.
There are no opportunities for advancement.  Since no one oversees your work, promotions are completely political and are only given if you are friendly/suck up to your supervisor.
There is ZERO mentoring.  I have been watching a junior associate struggle for months since she was hired, as no one from management has given her any supervision or direction.  She is already looking for a new position.
When another junior colleague was feeling overwhelmed (she had only been practicing in the respective area of law for  months) the supervisor was overheard she had to "get over it" and since the supervisor had figured it out "she would too".
This is not the supportive team environment that is typical to non-profits.

pros: Benefits here were generous at an entry level. Consistent hours and a stable work schedule. I enjoyed working with those in my unit very much.
cons: Management, like many other nonprofits I worked for, seemed a bit of a mess. The place is highly political, and I found it to be rather petty. Lots of division from department to department. HR is a mess and understaffed.

pros: Never bored. Flexible work hours
cons: Serious micromanagement and control issues in LegalHealth . Text book Founder's Syndrome... management needs to be involved in every opportunity and do not allow staff autonomy in managing their own clinics or pursuing opportunities but provide no general guidance.  Caseloads are brutal and attorneys must manage complex issues with little to no experience. Staff professional opinions on case management is frequently ignored

pros: Depending on which unit you're in, you can be exposed to many different types of cases and learn different skills important to the legal industry.  Many great people willing to teach you.
cons: No opportunity for advancement due to a very stratified management system.  It seems as though many are treated as perpetual interns even though they take on very advanced work.

review_title: Very impactful work! Huge opportunity to handle a large caseload and learn about civil law.
pros: Mission-driven organization with lots of opportunities to learn a lot and take on a lot of responsibilities.
cons: Sometimes the paralegals are given too much work; upper-management could be more organized, especially when it comes to internal referrals and giving paralegals support.

review_title: Law School Intern: Public Benefits Unit
pros: Interns and volunteers really feel welcomed and valued as part of the organization. I had my own email address and work space. Great staff attorneys who are dedicated to serving their clients and the community. Friendly environment. Not stuffy. Great place to work.
cons: There are so many people, staff, interns that you might have to make an extra effort to get to know people outside  your department.

review_title: Great environment to hone your skills and give back to the less fortunate.

pros:
A lot of meaningful work as both volunteer and salaried attorney,
Majority of departments with collaborative, friendly staff.
cons: Not enough mentoring in some smaller units. some project supervisors do not have a supervisor and are not good at giving feedback for your work.

pros: Great entry level job. Through the work and my colleagues, I realized I wanted to go to law school, stay in public interest, and stay working in the same subject matter.
cons: Hard to move up as a paralegal unless you go to law school. Like all nonprofits it's underfunded and underresourced.

job_title: Language Access Volunteer in New York, NY

job_title: Junior Attorney in New York, NY
pros: NYLAG has a lot of talented and passionate lawyers in many practice areas. I found it easy to share resources across practice groups and learned a lot there. For a nonprofit group, they also have nice offices.
cons: Felt large and bureaucratic at times, but most of your interaction will be with your own practice group.

pros: Good people who are passionate about their work. Client-centered and true to their mission. They just hired consultants, a good move I think.
